_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

HollyFrontier Cheyenne

Frontier Refining LLC.            

Risk Management Program

 

HollyFrontier's Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



It is HollyFrontier's policy to design, construct, operate, and maintain the equipment at the Cheyenne Refinery so that no accidental releases of any chemical occur that would negatively impact people or the environment.  To this end, HollyFrontier's staff strives to conduct all activities in accordance with industry standards.  HollyFrontier considers safety as a condition of employment and stresses safety in the workplace.  Personnel are required to demonstrate their commitment to safety by regularly attending safety meetings and undergoing regular refresher training on safety and environmental topics.  They are also encouraged to be involved in the facility's hazard identification program and union-lead incident and near-miss investigation programs.

 

Source Description and Part 68 Regulated Substances Handled 



HollyFrontier Refining LLC's (HollyFrontier's) Cheyenne Refinery processes approximately 52,000 barrels per day of crude oil supplied from Canada, Wyoming, and adjacent states.  The refinery consists of a variety of process units that separate, chemically react, and finally blend the crude oil components into gasoline, diesel, asphalt, petroleum coke, and other products.  In addition, the refinery has over one hundred storage tanks for storing the raw materials, intermediates, and products prior to shipment by pipeline or truck. The refinery's process units containing RMP-covered flammable materials are considered a single program 3 covered process.

 

Two 40 CFR Part 68 regulated substances are present in the process at the HollyFrontier facility in amounts above the specified threshold quantities.  These substances are common to most petroleum refineries and are:

 

-    NFPA 4 flammable mixtures that contain one of more of the following RMP-regulated substances; hydrogen, m

ethane, ethane, propane, propylene (1-propene), butane, isobutane, butene, and/or pentane.  These substances are chemically reacted and/or blended into gasoline and are flammable or explosive under certain conditions.



-    Hydrogen fluoride (HF), used as a catalyst in HollyFrontier's Alkylation Unit.  HF is a gas at normal conditions and is toxic above a certain concentration in the air.

 

HollyFrontier's Accidental Release Program & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



HollyFrontier implements and administers the RMP accidental release program in conjunction with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program, which requires the same program elements.  HollyFrontier has an individual designated as the Process Safety Manager who is responsible for the implementation and administration of the program.  

 

NFPA 4 flammable mixtures are present in several areas throughout the plant.  HollyFrontier's personnel are trained to be very aware of hydrocarbon leaks.  Through the Hot Work Permit program and the Leak Detection and Repair (LDAR) program, regular monitoring is conducted with calibrated instruments to check for and direct the repair of leaks.  Operators in all units have hand-held monitors for the detection of hydrocarbons, and several units have fixed hydrocarbon detectors.  HollyFrontier also maintains firewater monitors, deluge systems, and water curtains near the areas in which flammable mixtures are processed/present.  

 

HF acid is present only in the Alkylation Unit.  All personnel entering the unit receive special HF acid training prior to being allowed to enter.  HollyFrontier's personnel are trained to be very aware of HF leaks.  In addition, equipment connections are painted with a reactive paint that changes color in the presence of HF.  This provides indication of any leak at a connection.  In addition to the HF-specific measures, the measures outlined previously for NFPA 4 flammable substances also apply at the Alkylation Unit.  These measures

are effective at detecting and mitigating HF leaks, since in most places in the unit, hydrocarbons are present with the HF acid, and HF acid is very soluble in water.  Open-path hydrocarbon monitors are installed in the unit.  Finally, closed-circuit video cameras are placed throughout the unit to aid the operators' monitoring of the unit and direct the deluge water cannons in the event of a release.

 

HollyFrontier's Five Year Accident History



In accordance with the RMP rule, an accidental release must be included in the Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) if it involves a regulated substance released from a covered process that results in death, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  In the past five years, HollyFrontier has had no accidental release from the covered process that met these criteria.  

 

HollyFrontier's Emergency Response Program



General

All refinery personnel, contract workers, and unescorted visitors are required to complete an annual basic facility hazards awareness program prior to proceeding onto the operational areas of the refinery.  This program includes how to recognize emergency alarms and what to do in the event an alarm is sounded.   

 

HollyFrontier Employees

A majority of the refinery's non-managerial and non-administrative employees, as well as some contractors undergo annual first responder training (approximately three hours).  This covers usage of a self-contained breathing apparatus, basic awareness of HollyFrontier's firefighting and spill response equipment, fire extinguisher training on a live fire, and usage of a fire hose.

 

Fire Brigade

HollyFrontier's Fire Brigade is comprised of facility personnel that respond to refinery emergency situations involving fires and/or hazardous materials, including those subject to RMP.  Fire Brigade personnel receive an initial 32-hour training in industrial fir

efighting at either Texas A&M University Fire School or University of Nevada-Elko Fire Science Academy and an initial 24-hour OSHA Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) training held locally.  The Fire Brigade personnel also drill once a month for approximately four hours, attend an eight-hour HAZWOPER refresher course annually, and attend another 32-hour industrial firefighting course every three years.  Twenty-three personnel are also certified as structural firefighters and can back up the City of Cheyenne Fire Rescue personnel on structure fires if needed.

 

HollyFrontier maintains an off-site firehouse with several firefighting vehicles: a fast-attack truck, a 1250-gallon foam pumper, a 1250-gpm pumper engine (foam-capable), a 2000-gpm "Hired Gun" self-educting foam nozzle trailer, and a 1200-gallon foam nurse trailer.  A 1250-gpm "Telesquirt" pumper/ladder engine and a hazardous materials (HAZMAT) response trailer are stored offsite.  The HAZMAT trailer contains equipment primarily for spill containment, decontamination and cleanup.  HollyFrontier also maintains a live firefighting facility onsite.

 

Medical Personnel

A team of HollyFrontier's employees are trained to respond to medical injuries to the Basic Emergency Care level.  This training consists of an initial 40-hour training as well as ongoing continuing education requirements and biannual certification.  HollyFrontier also has a nurse on duty at the facility and several employees who are certified Emergency Medical Technicians.  HollyFrontier retains a company doctor who has an office off site.

 

Incident Command 

HollyFrontier has several employees trained as Incident Commanders using the National Interagency Incident Management System (NIIMS) Incident Command System (ICS).  These employees have received an initial eight-hour training in ICS.  HollyFrontier conducts tabletop ICS drills approximately once a month.  Each incident commander, as well as other employees ser

ving in the ICS, attend approximately two such drills per year.

 

Offsite Responders Coordination

HollyFrontier's Fire Brigade participates in drills with the City of Cheyenne Fire Rescue once or twice a year and HollyFrontier is a member of, and the Fire Chief participates in, the Laramie County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Emergency releases and significant fires are reported to the local 911, the Laramie County Emergency Management Agency, the Wyoming Office of Homeland Security, the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, and/or the National Response Center, as regulations require.  

 

HollyFrontier is a founding member of the Laramie County Industrial Mutual Aid Organization, which includes the City and County fire departments as well as several industrial and military fire departments in the area.  The mutual aid organization can provide additional response equipment, materials, and personnel in the event of a large emergency.  The organization maintains and updates a directory of mutual aid resources.

  

Community Monitoring

HollyFrontier maintains equipment for two offsite incident response kits to aid in monitoring the community in the event of a release of a hazardous/toxic chemical.  These kits include instruments for detecting hydrocarbons, hydrofluoric acid, hydrogen sulfide, and sulfur dioxide; hand-held meteorological instruments; maps and digital cameras for documentation; and emergency response information (both general and chemical-specific).

 

Community Notification

In the event of an emergency event or a non-emergency event that may be mistaken for an emergency (e.g. fire training exercise), HollyFrontier contacts the city 911 operator.  In the case of a large or highly visible event, the Laramie County Emergency Management Agency (LCEMA) may be notified as well.  Any community notifications, whether for informational purposes only, shelter-in-place, or evacuations, are handled through the 911 operator or the LCEMA.

These public agencies have the following notification methods at their disposal:

 

-    Outdoor warning sirens:  Approximately 34 sirens are located in Cheyenne.

-    Emergency Alert System:  A system through which local radio and television outlets distribute emergency information.

-    "Code Red":  A 'reverse-911'- type automatic telephone notification system that can send pre-recorded messages about an emergency at the rate of 60,000 calls per hour.  HollyFrontier funds 50% of the annual fee associated with the program.

 

Finally, HollyFrontier's own refinery sirens are audible to the nearby community and would likely be the first alert heard in the event of a chemical emergency.

 

HollyFrontier also participates in the county's Shelter In Place program.  This program is a countywide effort to provide information and procedures for citizens on how to survive a chemical emergency in their homes or other buildings when evacuation could be more dangerous.  The aforementioned systems and programs are communicated directly to the local residents and other potentially impacted populace by a variety of people and organizations, including city and county officials, senior refinery management, and through the county's website (www.laramiecounty.com)

 

HollyFrontier's Planned Changes to Improve Safety at the Facility



HollyFrontier has implemented each of the following safety improvements since the previous RMP submission:



?    Standardized and replaced a large percentage of the SCBA bottles used by the ERT 

?    Implemented the USW TOP program for incident investigation and near miss reporting

?    Made significant revisions to the majority of key safety policies (i.e. LOTO, Confined Space, Cranes, etc.)

?    Implemented Life Saving Principles

?    Implemented permit audit program

?    Implemented the contractor DISA program

?    Implemented the HAZ-Aware program

?    Formed the Contractor Safety Committee

?    Installed closed loop sample stations in multiple units

?    Improved vapo

r recovery system on rail rack

?    Improved bullet tank level indication

?    Made multiple pump seal upgrades (installed tandem seals)

?    Upgraded the plant alarm system

?    Made capital investment in new fireproofing



Additionally, the following safety improvements are planned prior to the next 5-year RMP submission:



?    Installing an EIV on the crude fractionator bottoms

?    Upgrading the radio system

?    Installing new view-ports and additional tube skin TIs in platformer heaters

?    Upgrading the FRC program 

?    Long term Fire Water System Improvement Plan is being developed to improve capacity and reliability
